bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, January 3, 1952

div1.p: Hench is concerned about his responsibilities connected with the Congress on Nutrition and Vitaminology in Havana. He has received conflicting information regarding dates and paper submissions.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Tom D. Spies, January 3, 1952
div1.opener:
January 3, 1952
Dr. Tom D. Spies
Nutrition Clinic
Hillman Hospital
Birmingham, Alabama
My dear Tom:
div1.p:
I am sending you herewith two copies of my semi-final, unedited version. But
I really don't know exactly for what purpose it is to be used.

In writing you the following, please do not consider me as being critical of
you or my other hosts but I have been disturbed to find that my understanding
of the responsibilities which I took on when I accepted this kind invitation
has been confused if not incorrect and as a result of the confusion I have
had to drop other urgent material and prepare the enclosed preliminary manu-
script a couple of weeks before I thought I would have to do so and even now
am sending you a manuscript which is certainly too long for presentation,
which must be revised here and there and which is undoubtedly too long for
publication in your proceedings.

I have had to spend much of my Christmas week, daytime as well as evenings,
preparing this tentative draft and as I say, I don't quite know why but
let me review some of our correspondence to show you at least the source
of some of my confusion. I realize of course that in organizing this congress
you have been carrying on undoubtedly an extensive correspondence with many
people and cannot be expected to remember exactly what you might have told
any one man at any one time.

Regarding the duration of the congress, in your letter of July 25 to me you
stated that the congress would be held “between the 20th and 26th of January.”
These dates were repeated in your letter of August 3, “The congress itself
will be from the 20th of January through the 26th.” But on September 8 I
had a letter from Doctor Vieta which stated that the congress “will take
place in Havana, Cuba, Friday January 25. It will begin at 8:30 a.m. and
it will end at 6 p.m.” When I then wrote and asked you for clarification
of this apparent contradiction, you wrote me on September 21 that there
would be a number of functions that you would like to have me attend if
I could be there on the 23rd and 24th. You did not tell me what these
functions were. In your letter of October 1 you stated that “The Cubans
may have Latin speakers on the 23rd and 24th or may decide to have a function
for the North Americans....The 25th is North American Day.” I still am
uncertain as to what obligations I will have on the 23rd or 24th or on the
evening of the 25th. If the papers are all in Spanish on the 23rd and 24th
as your letter implies and also are all on metabolism and nutrition, I had
not expected to attend those meetings, but of course I will do what you wish
me to do and will attend what functions it seems appropriate for me to attend.

However I do wish that you would clarify my confusion. I would like to
know just what I am getting into, whether there are other times when I
might be called upon for discussions, informal remarks or luncheon or
dinner remarks. I am no good at impromptu speaking. I am willing to
tackle whatever is expected of me but only if I know ahead of time and can
collect my thoughts.

Regarding the title of my talk, that was requested by you on September 15
and was sent to you by me on September 18.

Regarding a summary of the talk, Doctor Vieta's letter of September 8 and
your previous correspondence made no mention of a summary being necessary.
In your letter of November 7 you ask for a summary, to be translated into
Spanish for the program. I had to write you and tell you unfortunately that
for many months now my obligations have been such that I have gone from one
responsibility to another, finishing each just in the nick of time and have
been rarely able to start whatever I had to do for the next meeting more than
a couple of weeks ahead of time; therefore I asked you to be indulgent with
me and told you that I had a number of things to do before I could get to the
summary or the paper, not one word of which I had yet written. I was unable
to get this for you until a short time ago and I am sure that you now have it.

Regarding publication of the paper, from my conversations with you and your
early letters, I was led to believe that my participation in the congress was
to be a rather casual one, that you didn't care much what I talked about and
in reviewing our correspondence between April 16 and September 15, no mention
was made of publication. In my last paragraph to you, letter of September 18,
I stated “If I remember rightly you told me I would not have to publish the
paper. This would be a great help.” I continued to assume that because in
your letters of September 21 and 26 there was no mention of publication.
But “the blow fell” when you wrote me on October 1 and stated that you did want
“a brief paper to be published “in a little volume” put out by the Journal
of Vitamin Research. I assumed that this volume would constitute a record of
the proceedings of the congress and not having heard of such a volume being
put out before the Congress, I assumed that I would certainly not have to
have anything but a speaking version ready before the Congress. But in your
letter of October 16 you first stated that you wanted my paper “well in ad-
vance of the meeting as the Journal wants to set up the issue so that it can
be published promptly.” Although I was greatly concerned about the need for
having any kind of a formal or semi-formal manuscript before the meeting (other
than a speaking version and an abstract), I assumed still that publication of
the paper by the journal would occur of course sometime after the congress
and this notion seemed to be confirmed by the remark in your letter of Novem-
ber 7 that you wanted the summary ahead of time for translation into Spanish
for the programs. Therefore I was considerably disturbed when, on November 9,
I received from Miss Maria Luisa Mas, Executive Secretary of FIM, a request
for my whole paper. I wrote her that I was so involved in other work that I
could not finish it much before the first of the year. I asked her whether
she needed for translation in the program an abstract or the whole paper.
This was in my letter to her of November 20, but I had no reply. In your
letter of November 21 you requested an abstract or the paper for translation
for the program. Then in your letter of December 13, instead of asking for
the abstract or paper, you asked for the abstract and paper, to be sent off
to the journal.

I think, Tom, you will see, if you have read the above with patience and
not too much annoyance at me, the source of my confusion. As the requests
changed from one thing to another, there was nothing I could do about it as
I had already committed myself irrevocably to certain undeniable obliga-
tions. For example, I have given two rather important after-dinner banquet
talks recently, the talks to be published, and I have been working on two
manuscripts that had to be presented in New York recently. I just want you
to understand why you are now receiving a version which I certainly don't
want published as it is, either before or after the meeting. As I said above,
the manuscript needs revision and much condensation and shortening for the
purposes of your journal. Because since only a relatively small part of the
paper concerns nutrition and vitamins, you will want me to preserve that in
toto and sharply abstract most of the rest.

You will ask me why did I write this sort of a version to begin with. Again
I must tell you that I am in the position of not being able to write a new
paper just for one function and I have promised to give another talk in
January; therefore this paper as you are receiving it, is really for that
meeting and an abstract of this paper was to be for your meeting. Each
of us has his own way of working and I modify my methods somewhat to suit
the requirements, but in this instance, because of the fact that I was
trying to kill two birds with one stone, I had to write the long version
first and then will make an abstract.

Now, if despite the uncertainties in the correspondence, the Journal of
Vitamin Research is about to publish this almost immediately, I think
they will have to do one of three things: (a) Omit my paper and merely
publish the abstract that I sent you, of (b) Wait until I can make an
abstract of this version which will be done in the next two weeks but
which probably will not be edited with all the bibliography, etc., until
after I return from Cuba, or (c) Have someone make whatever sort of on
short version of this they think is suitable for the Journal and then, above
all, send that to our Editorial Department for their quick review and ap-
proval. Our Editorial Department would certainly not be happy if I published
anything that did not go through their department. That is an established
policy of the Clinic which has been extremely useful for all of us.

Now, Tom, as I say, I hope that having called the above things to your
attention will not annoy you. I feel that since I have not been able
to fulfill the recent requests which you and Miss Mas made, that I
perhaps might be considered guilty of having misunderstood the obliga-
tions, If i id, it was from lack of specific information early enough
and because of the apparent confusion and changing request which I have
mentioned above. Actually, I have yet to outline my slides. They must
be done in the next two weeks because I want now slides made as I am
sick and tired of the papers that I have given during 1951 and regarding
that, feel very talked out indeed.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
